{{Infobox NFL player |image=Patrick Chung.JPG |image_size=250 |caption=Chung with the Patriots in 2017 |current_team = New England Patriots |number=23 |position=[[Safety (American football position)|Strong safety]] |birth_date={{birth date and age|1987|8|19}} |birth_place=[[Kingston, Jamaica]] |height_ft = 5 |height_in = 11 |weight_lbs = 215 |high_school = [[Rancho Cucamonga High School|Rancho Cucamonga]]
{{nowrap|([[Rancho Cucamonga, California]])}} |college=[[Oregon Ducks football|Oregon]] |draftyear=2009 |draftround=2 |draftpick=34 |pastteams= * [[New England Patriots]] ({{NFL Year|2009}}–{{NFL Year|2012}}) * [[Philadelphia Eagles]] ({{NFL Year|2013}}) * New England Patriots ({{NFL Year|2014}}–present) |status=Active |highlights= * 2× [[Super Bowl]] champion ([[Super Bowl XLIX|XLIX]], [[Super Bowl LI|LI]]) * Second-team [[All-American]] ([[2007 College Football All-America Team|2007]]) * 2× First-team All-[[Pacific-10 Conference|Pac-10]] (2007, 2008) * First-team Freshman All America (2005) * Oregon record for defensive starts (51) |statweek=12 |statseason=2018 |statlabel1=[[Tackle (football move)|Total tackles]] |statvalue1=704 |statlabel2=[[Quarterback sack|Sacks]] |statvalue2=4.5 |statlabel3=[[Pass deflections]] |statvalue3=54 |statlabel4=[[Interceptions]] |statvalue4=11 |statlabel5=[[Fumble|Forced fumbles]] |statvalue5=1 |statlabel6=[[Touchdown|Defensive touchdowns]] |statvalue6=1 |nfl=CHU126772 }} '''Patrick Christopher Chung''' (born August 19, 1987) is an [[American football]] [[Safety (American football position)|strong safety]] for the [[New England Patriots]] of the [[National Football League]]. He was drafted by the Patriots in the second round of the [[2009 NFL Draft]]. He played [[college football]] at [[Oregon Ducks football|Oregon]] and has also been a member of the [[Philadelphia Eagles]]. ==Early life== Chung was born in [[Kingston, Jamaica]]. He has four brothers and three sisters.{{cite web|url=http://www.goducks.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=500&ATCLID=753208|title=Patrick Chung Collegiate Player Page|publisher=GoDucks.com|accessdate= October 6, 2013}} Chung lived in Jamaica until he was ten before moving to California, where he attended [[Rancho Cucamonga High School]] in [[Rancho Cucamonga, California]]; he played [[high school football|football]] as a safety and [[wide receiver]] and was a two-time All-League pick.http://www.patriots.com/team/players/roster/patrick-chung ==College career== Chung enrolled at the [[University of Oregon]] in 2004.{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/blog/boston/new-england-patriots/post/_/id/4685729/football-journey-patrick-chung|title=Football journey: Patrick Chung|work=ESPNBoston.com|first=Mike|last=Reiss|date=2010-10-23|accessdate=2010-10-28}} After [[Redshirt (college sports)|redshirt]]ing in 2004, Chung took over at the "rover" position in 2005, ranking second on the team with 91 tackles (5 solo), as he caused a fumble and deflected five passes. He earned All-[[Pacific-10 Conference]] honorable mention honors, and a spot on the [[Sporting News]] Freshman All-American Team. In 2006, Chung once again earned All-Pac-10 honorable mention, finishing third on the team with 84 tackles, two sacks, and four interceptions.{{Cite web |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/players/patrick-chung-1/gamelog/2006/ |title=Patrick Chung 2006 Game Log |website=College Football at Sports-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2017-12-29}} As a junior, Chung was named Second Team All-American and first-team All-Pac-10 Conference. He received the Gordon E. Wilson Award, given to the team's top special teams player. He averaged 22.3 yards on nine kickoff returns while leading the Ducks with a career-high 117 tackles (71 solos), adding 7.5 stops for loss. He broke up nine passes and was credited with a pair of interceptions.{{Cite web |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/players/patrick-chung-1/gamelog/2007/ |title=Patrick Chung 2007 Game Log |website=College Football at Sports-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2017-12-29}} Chung garnered Third Team All-American accolades in addition to making the All-Pac 10 first-team for the second consecutive year in 2008. Along with offensive lineman [[Max Unger]], the pair set the school record with 51 consecutive starting assignments. He had 92 tackles (58 solos) in 13 games, coming up with two sacks among his 6.5 stops for loss. He caused and recovered a fumble, batted down seven passes and returned his only interception 31 yards for a touchdown.{{Cite web |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/players/patrick-chung-1/gamelog/2008/ |title=Patrick Chung 2008 Game Log |website=College Football at Sports-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2017-12-29}} Chung holds the distinction of starting more games than any other defensive player in Oregon history, having started 51 straight games during his collegiate career.{{cite web|url=http://www.nfl.com/draft/2009/profiles/patrick-chung?id=71251|title=Patrick Chung (SS)|publisher=NFL.com|accessdate=2009-04-26}} ==Professional career== On January 16, 2008, it was announced that Chung had decided to forgo his last year of eligibility and enter the [[2008 NFL Draft]].{{cite web| title=Chung to skip final year of eligibility, enter draft| url=http://www.espn.com/nfl/draft08/news/story?id=3199445| accessdate=April 24, 2018| website=ESPN.com| author=Len Pasquarelli| date=January 16, 2008}} Three days later, Chung announced that he decided to instead return to Oregon for his senior year.{{cite web| title=2008 NFL Draft Early Entries| url=https://www.sportsagentblog.com/2008/01/19/2008-nfl-draft-early-entries/| accessdate=April 24, 2018| website=sportsagentblog.com| date=January 19, 2008}} On January 24, 2009, Chung participated in the [[2009 Senior Bowl]] as part of [[Cincinnati Bengals|Cincinnati Bengals']] head coach [[Marvin Lewis|Marvin Lewis']] North team that lost 18–35 to the South.{{cite web| title=Patriots' team report: New England grabs S Chung| url=http://www.sportingnews.com/nfl/news/100913-patriots-team-report-new-england-grabs-s-chung| accessdate=April 24, 2018| website=sportingnews.com| date=April 25, 2009}} He went on to attend the [[NFL Scouting Combine]] and completed the majority of drills before sustaining a knee injury. He was unable to perform the short shuttle and three-cone drill due to the injury. On March 12, 2009, he attended Oregon's pro day and ran the short shuttle, three-cone drill, and positional drills. At the conclusion of the pre-draft process, he was projected to be a second round pick by NFL draft experts and scouts.{{cite web| title=Patrick Chung, DS #1 SS, Oregon| url=http://draftscout.com/ratings/dsprofile.php?pyid=58091&draftyear=2009&genpos=| accessdate=April 24, 2018| website=DraftScout.com}} Chung was ranked as the top strong safety prospect in the draft by DraftScout.com and was ranked the second best safety by NFL analyst [[Mike Mayock]].{{cite web| title=Mayock's top prospects at each position| url=http://www.nfl.com/draft/story/09000d5d80dff358/article/mayocks-top-prospects-at-each-position| accessdate=April 24, 2018| website=NFL.com| author=Mayock, Mike| date=April 24, 2009}} {{Nfl predraft | height ft = 5 | height in = 11¼ | weight = 212 | dash = 4.59 | ten split = 1.58 | twenty split = 2.57 | shuttle = 4.24 | cone drill = 7.11 | vertical = 34 | broad ft = 9 | broad in = 11 | bench = 25 | wonderlic =23 | arm span = | hand span = | note = All values from [[NFL Combine]]/[[Oregon Ducks football|Oregon's Pro Day]] }} ===New England Patriots=== The [[New England Patriots]] selected Chung in the second round (34th overall) of the [[2009 NFL Draft]]. Chung was the second safety drafted in 2009, one pick behind [[Western Michigan Broncos football|Western Michigan]] safety [[Louis Delmas]].{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/years/2009/draft.htm |title=2009 NFL Draft Listing |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2017-12-29}} ====2009==== On July 27, 2009, the [[New England Patriots]] signed Chung to a four-year, [[United States dollar|$]]5 million contract that includes a [[signing bonus]] of $2 million.{{cite web| title=Spotrac.com: Patrick Chung contract| url=http://www.spotrac.com/nfl/new-england-patriots/patrick-chung-5805/| accessdate=April 24, 2018| website=Spotrac.com}}{{cite web| title=2010 New England Patriots Salary Cap| url=http://www.patscap.com/2010capfootnotes.html| accessdate=April 24, 2018| website=patscap.com}} Defensive coordinator [[Dean Pees]] held a competition to name to new starting safeties between Chung, [[Brandon Meriweather]], [[James Sanders (American football)|James Sanders]], and [[Brandon McGowan]].{{cite web| title=New England Patriots: Six Position Battles To Watch This Summer| url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/224001-new-england-patriots-five-position-battles-to-watch-this-summer| accessdate=April 24, 2018| website=bleacherreport.com| author=Johnson, Alex| date=July 25, 2009}}{{cite web| title=Pat's sign ex-Bears S McGowan| url=https://www.nfl.com/news/story/09000d5d8102b59d/article/patriots-add-to-depth-at-safety-by-signing-mcgowan| accessdate=April 25, 2018| website=NFL.com| date=May 5, 2009}} Head coach [[Bill Belichick]] named Chung the backup strong safety to begin the regular season, behind Brandon Meriweather.{{cite web| title=Ourlads.com: New England Patriots Depth Chart: 09/06/2009| url=http://www.ourlads.com/nfldepthcharts/archive/40/NE| accessdate=April 24, 2018| website=Ourlads.com}} He made his professional regular season debut in the [[2009 New England Patriots|New England Patriots']] season-opener against the [[2009 Buffalo Bills|Buffalo Bills]] and recorded one tackle in their 25–24 victory. Chung made his first career tackle with teammate [[Darius Butler]] on cornerback [[Leodis McKelvin]] during a 21-yard kick return in the fourth quarter.{{cite web| title=NFL Game Center: Week 1-2009: Buffalo Bills @ New England Patriots| url=http://www.ourlads.com/nfldepthcharts/archive/40/NE| accessdate=April 24, 2018| website=NFL.com}} On October 16, 2009, Chung collected a season-high eight combined tackles, deflected a pass, and made his first career interception off a pass by quarterback [[Vince Young]] as the Patriots routed the [[2009 Tennessee Titans|Tennessee Titans]] 59–0 in Week 6.{{cite web| title=NFL Game Center: Week 6-2009: Tennessee Titans @ New England Patriots| url=http://www.nfl.com/gamecenter/2009101810/2009/REG6/titans@patriots#tab=recap| accessdate=April 24, 2018| website=NFL.com}} The following week, he collected four solo tackles and made his first career sack on quarterback [[Josh Johnson (quarterback)|Josh Johnson]] in the Patriots' 35–7 in over the [[2009 Tampa Bay Buccaneers|Tampa Bay Buccaneers]] at [[Wembley Stadium]] in Week 7.{{cite web| title=NFL Game Center: Week 7-2009: New England Patriots @ Tampa Bay Buccaneers| url=http://www.nfl.com/gamecenter/2009102506/2009/REG7/patriots@buccaneers#tab=recap| accessdate=April 25, 2018| website=NFL.com}} In Week 10, Chung earned his first career start and recorded five combined tackles during a 35–34 loss at the [[2009 Indianapolis Colts|Indianapolis Colts]].{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/200910180nwe.htm |title=Tennessee Titans at New England Patriots - October 18th, 2009 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2017-12-29}} He finished his rookie season with 37 combined tackles (25 solo), two sacks, a pass deflection, and an interception in 16 games and one start.{{cite web| title=NFL Player stats: Patrick Chung (career)| url=http://www.nfl.com/player/patrickchung/71251/careerstats| accessdate=April 24, 2018| website=NFL.com}} The New England Patriots finished first in the [[AFC East]] with a 10–6 record. On January 10, 2010, Chung appeared in his first career playoff game as the Patriots were defeated 33–14 by the [[2009 Baltimore Ravens|Baltimore Ravens]] in the AFC Wildcard Game.{{cite web| title=NFL Player stats: Patrick Chung (2009)| url=http://www.nfl.com/player/patrickchung/71251/gamelogs?season=2009| accessdate=April 25, 2018| website=NFL.com}} ====2010==== On January 15, 2010, it was reported that defensive coordinator Dean Pees would not be renewing his contract or returning to the Patriots. Head coach Bill Belichick took over defensive coordinator duties for the season.{{cite web| title=Coaching staff undergoing changes| url=http://www.patriots.com/news/2010/02/05/coaching-staff-undergoing-changes| accessdate=April 25, 2018| website=Patriots.com| date=February 5, 2010}}{{cite web| title=Pees not see contract renewal| url=http://www.espn.com/boston/nfl/news/story?id=4826721| accessdate=April 25, 2018| website=ESPN.com| author=Reiss, Mike| date=January 15, 2010}} Chung competed for the job as the starting strong safety against Brandon McGowan and James Sanders.{{cite web| title=Chung's development a key for Patriots| url=http://www.espn.com/boston/nfl/columns/story?columnist=reiss_mike&id=5261367| accessdate=April 25, 2018| website=ESPN.com| author=Reiss, Mike| date=June 7, 2010}} He was officially named the starting strong safety to start the regular season, along with free safety Brandon Meriweather.{{cite web| title=Ourlads.com: New England Patriots Depth Chart: 09/05/2010| url=http://www.ourlads.com/nfldepthcharts/archive/111/NE| accessdate=April 25, 2018| website=Ourlads.com}} He started in the [[2010 New England Patriots|New England Patriots']] season-opener against the [[2010 Cincinnati Bengals|Cincinnati Bengals]] and collected a career-high 16 combined tackles (12 solo) in their 38–24 victory.{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201009120nwe.htm |title=Cincinnati Bengals at New England Patriots - September 12th, 2010 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2017-12-29}} On October 4, 2010, Chung made five combined tackles and returned an interception by [[Chad Henne]] for a 51-yard touchdown to mark the first score of his career. He also blocked a punt and a field goal as the Patriots routed the [[2010 Miami Dolphins|Miami Dolphins]] 41–14 on ''[[Monday Night Football]]'' in Week 4.{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201010040mia.htm |title=New England Patriots at Miami Dolphins - October 4th, 2010 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2017-12-29}} In Week 6, he collected 13 combined tackles (five solo) in a 23–20 win against the [[2010 Baltimore Ravens|Baltimore Ravens]].{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201010170nwe.htm |title=Baltimore Ravens at New England Patriots - October 17th, 2010 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2017-12-29}} The following week, Chung made a tackle before exiting a 23–20 win against the [[2010 San Diego Chargers|San Diego Chargers]] after injuring his knee. He was sidelined for the next two games (Weeks 8–9) due to the knee injury.{{cite web| title=Patriots-Browns Injury Report - 11/5/2010| url=http://www.patriots.com/news/2010/11/05/patriots-browns-injury-report-1152010| accessdate=April 25, 2018| website=Patriots.com| date=November 5, 2010}} He finished the {{NFL Year|2010}} season with 96 combined tackles (72 solo), nine pass deflections, three interceptions, and a touchdown in 14 games and 13 starts.{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/players/C/ChunPa99/gamelog/2010/ |title=Patrick Chung 2010 Game Log |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2017-12-29}} The New England Patriots finished atop their division with a 14–2 record, clinching a first round bye and home-field advantage. On January 16, 2011, Chung made his first career start in a playoff game and recorded four solo tackles during a 28–21 loss to the [[2010 New York Jets|New York Jets]] in the AFC Divisional round.{{cite web| title=NFL Player stats: Patrick Chung (2010)| url=http://www.nfl.com/player/patrickchung/71251/gamelogs?season=2010| accessdate=April 25, 2018| website=NFL.com}} With 1:14 left in the second quarter, Chung made the decision to call an audible on a punt and opted to receive a direct snap from the longsnapper on a trick play instead and attempt to gain four-yards for the first down. He botched the direct snap and recovered the fumble for no gain at New England's 37-yard line.{{cite web| title=NFL Game Center: Week 19-2010: New York Jets @ New England Patriots| url=http://www.nfl.com/gamecenter/2011011600/2010/POST19/jets@patriots#tab=recap| accessdate=April 25, 2018| website=NFL.com}} The mistake proved costly as the New York Jets capitalized on their field position and scored a touchdown in four plays and 41 seconds to enter half time leading the Patriots 14–3.{{cite web| title=Safety Patrick Chung growing into leadership role with Patriots as he enters third season| url=http://blog.masslive.com/patriots/2011/08/safety_patrick_chung_growing_i.html| accessdate=April 25, 2018| website=MassLive.com| date=August 11, 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/thehuddle/post/2011/01/patrick-chung-not-bill-belichick-called-patriots-botched-fake-punt/1|title=Patrick Chung, not Bill Belichick, called Patriots' botched fake punt|work=[[USA Today]]|first=Sean|last=Leahy|date=2011-01-17|accessdate=2011-01-17}} Chung accepted responsibility for the mistake and stated it was his decision to call for the direct snap. He explained that he called the audible after discovering the Patriots had an eight on six advantage with their blocking scheme.{{cite web| title=Zoltan Mesko reveals botched fake punt was Patrick Chung's call| url=https://nesn.com/2011/01/zoltan-mesko-reveals-botched-fake-punt-was-patrick-chungs-call/| accessdate=April 25, 2018| website=NESN.com| date=January 17, 2011| author=Howe, Jeff}} ====2011==== Chung entered training camp slated as the starting strong safety and was officially named the starter to begin the regular season, opposite free safety Brandon Meriweather. On September 18, 2011, Chung made five combined tackles during a 35–21 win against the [[2011 San Diego Chargers|San Diego Chargers]] in Week 2. He exited the game in the third quarter and returned with a hard cast around his thumb in the fourth quarter.{{cite web| title=Safety Patrick Chung Is Patriots’ Latest Victim of Thumb-Injury Epidemic| url=https://nesn.com/2011/09/safety-patrick-chung-is-patriots-latest-victim-of-thumb-injury-epidemic/| accessdate=April 25, 2018| website=nesn.com| author=Howe, Jeff| date=September 19, 2011}} Chung was inactive for the Patriots' Week 3 loss at the [[2011 Buffalo Bills|Buffalo Bills]] after he underwent surgery to repair his fractured thumb.{{cite web| title=Report: Patriots safety Patrick Chung had thumb surgery performed this week| url=http://blog.masslive.com/patriots/2011/09/report_patriots_safety_patrick.html| accessdate=April 25, 2018| website=blog.masslive.com| author=Underhill, Nick| date=September 21, 2011}} On October 30, 2011, he collected a season-high 13 combined tackles (ten solo) and broke up a pass in the Patriots' 25–17 loss at the [[2011 Pittsburgh Steelers|Pittsburgh Steelers]] in Week 8. Chung was sidelined for seven consecutive games (Weeks 10–16) after suffering an injury to his foot.{{cite web| title=Patriots rule out safety Chung vs. Jets with foot injury| url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/09000d5d82415225/article/patriots-rule-out-safety-chung-vs-jets-with-foot-injury| accessdate=April 25, 2018| website=NFL.com| date=November 13, 2011}}{{cite web| title=Patrick Chung back on injury report| url=http://www.espn.com/boston/nfl/story/_/id/7459545/2011-nfl-playoffs-logan-mankins-patrick-chung-13-questionable-new-england-patriots| accessdate=April 25, 2018| website=ESPN.com| author=Rodak, Mike| date=January 14, 2012}} He finished the 2011 season with 62 combined tackles (37 solo), four pass deflections, an interception, and a sack in eight games and eight starts. The [[2011 New England Patriots|New England Patriots]] finished atop of the AFC East with a record of 13–3, clinching a first round bye and home-field advantage. They went on to defeat the [[2011 Denver Broncos|Denver Broncos]] in the AFC Divisional Round and the [[2011 Baltimore Ravens|Baltimore Ravens]] in the [[AFC Championship Game]].{{cite web| title=NFL Player stats: Patrick Chung (2011)| url=http://www.nfl.com/player/patrickchung/71251/gamelogs?season=2011| accessdate=April 25, 2018| website=NFL.com}} On February 5, 2012, Chung started in [[Super Bowl XLVI]] and recorded six combined tackles and a pass deflection in the Patriots' 21–17 loss to the [[2011 New York Giants season|New York Giants]].Aaron Fentress, "[http://www.oregonlive.com/ducks/index.ssf/2012/02/oregon_ducks_rundown_patrick_c.html Oregon Ducks rundown: Patrick Chung made biggest hit of Super Bowl XLVI but Spencer Paysinger earned a ring]", ''The Oregonian'' (Monday, February 6, 2012). ====2012==== Defensive coordinator [[Matt Patricia]] retained Chung as the starting strong safety, alongside free safety [[Steve Gregory (American football)|Steve Gregory]]. Chung started the first six games of the season before sustaining a shoulder injury and missing four games (Weeks 7–11). During his absence, he was replaced by [[Devin McCourty]], who was moved from cornerback to safety.{{cite web| title=Hernandez, Chung Out; 11 Questionable For Patriots Vs. Rams| url=http://boston.cbslocal.com/2012/10/26/hernanez-chung-out-11-questionable-for-patriots-vs-rams/| accessdate=April 25, 2018| website=boston.cbslocal.com| date=October 26, 2012}}/ Upon his return in Week 11, Chung was named the backup strong safety behind McCourty and was limited to 65 defensive snaps in the next four games (Weeks 11–14).{{cite web| title=Chung trying to keep up with Patriots defense| url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/sports/2012/12/21/patrick-chung-trying-keep-with-changing-patriots-defense/sdTuIRprk1IbnS2j9PSJSK/story.html| accessdate=April 25, 2018| website=bostonglobe.com| author=Benboe, Julian| date=December 22, 2012}} On December 23, 2012, Chung made four combined tackles, two pass deflections, and intercepted two passes by [[Chad Henne]] during a 23–16 win at the [[2012 Jacksonville Jaguars|Jacksonville Jaguars]] in Week 16. The following week, Chung collected a season-high six combined tackles and deflected a pass in the Patriots' 28–0 victory against the [[2012 Miami Dolphins|Miami Dolphins]] in Week 17.{{cite web| title=NFL Player stats: Patrick Chung (2012)| url=http://www.nfl.com/player/patrickchung/71251/gamelogs?season=2012| accessdate=April 25, 2018| website=NFL.com}} Chung finished the season with 44 combined tackles (29 solo), five pass deflections, and two interceptions in 12 games and eight starts. ===Philadelphia Eagles=== On March 12, 2013, the [[Philadelphia Eagles]] signed Chung to a three-year, $10 million contract with $4 million guaranteed. He was reunited with Eagles' head coach [[Chip Kelly]], who served as Oregon's offensive coordinator during Chung's last two years.{{cite web |last=Hughes |first=Luke |title=Patrick Chung Signs With Eagles, Reunites With College Coach Chip Kelly |url=http://nesn.com/2013/03/patrick-chung-signs-with-eagles-reunites-with-college-coach-chip-kelly/ |publisher=''NESN.com'' |date=March 12, 2013 |accessdate=2013-03-13}}{{cite web| title=Bill Belichick explains how Patrick Chung reinvented himself| url=http://www.nbcsports.com/philadelphia/philadelphia-eagles/bill-belichick-explains-how-patrick-chung-reinvented-himself| accessdate=April 25, 2018| website=nbcsports.com| author=Frank, Reuben| date=December 6, 2016}} [[File:RG3 eagles.JPG|thumb|left|225px|Chung (#23) pursuing Washington Redskins' quarterback [[Robert Griffin III]] in 2013.]] Defensive coordinator [[Billy Davis (American football coach)|Billy Davis]] held an open competition to name two new starting safeties. The competition included Chung, [[Kenny Phillips]], [[Colt Anderson]], [[Nate Allen (safety)|Nate Allen]], [[Kurt Coleman]], and [[David Sims (safety)|David Sims]].{{cite web| title=Chip Kelly and Eagles creating competition in key spots| url=https://www.bleedinggreennation.com/2013/3/16/4113310/chip-kelly-and-eagles-creating-competition-in-key-spots| accessdate=April 25, 2018| website=bleedinggreennation.com| author=Kaye, Mike| date=March 16, 2013}} Head coach Chip Kelly named him the starting free safety to begin the season, along with strong safety Nate Allen.{{cite web| title=Ourlads.com: Philadelphia Eagles Depth Chart; 09/05/2013| url=http://www.ourlads.com/nfldepthcharts/archive/150/PHI| accessdate=April 24, 2018| website=Ourlads.com}} He started in the [[2013 Philadelphia Eagles|Philadelphia Eagles']] season-opener at the [[2013 Washington Redskins|Washington Redskins]] and recorded seven combined tackles in their 33–27 victory. He was sidelined for two games (Weeks 4–5) due to a shoulder injury.{{cite web| title=Eagles injury update: S Patrick Chung and CB Brandon Boykin limited in practice| url=https://www.bleedinggreennation.com/2013/10/2/4795084/eagles-injury-update-s-patrick-chung-and-cb-brandon-boykin-limited-in| accessdate=April 25, 2018| website=bleedinggreennation.com| author=Kaye, Mike| date=October 2, 2013}} In Week 6, Chung made two combined tackles before exiting the Eagles' 31–20 win at the [[2013 Tampa Bay Buccaneers|Tampa Bay Buccaneers]] in the third quarter after aggravating his shoulder injury. He missed another two games due to the injury (Weeks 7–8) and lost his starting role to rookie [[Earl Wolff]]. Chung regained his starting role in Week 11 and started the last six games of the regular season after Wolff sustained a knee injury.{{cite web| title=Eagles Injury Update: Everyone Except Earl Wolff is Healthy| url=https://www.bleedinggreennation.com/platform/2013/11/26/5148608/eagles-injury-update-everyone-except-earl-wolff-healthy-michael-vick| accessdate=April 25, 2018| website=bleedinggreennation.com| author=Gowton, Brandon Lee| date=November 26, 2013}} On December 29, 2013, Chung collected a season-high ten combined tackles (five solo) during a 24–22 win at the [[2013 Dallas Cowboys|Dallas Cowboys]] in Week 17.{{cite web| title=NFL Player stats: Patrick Chung (2013)| url=http://www.nfl.com/player/patrickchung/71251/gamelogs?season=2013| accessdate=April 25, 2018| website=NFL.com}} He finished his only season with the Eagles with 59 combined tackles (39 solo) and three pass deflections in 12 games and ten starts. The Philadelphia Eagles finished first in the [[NFC East]] with a 10–6 record. On January 4, 2014, Chung made four solo tackles in the Eagles' 26–24 loss to the [[2013 New Orleans Saints|New Orleans Saints]] in the NFC Wildcard Game. ====2014==== On March 11, 2014, the Philadelphia Eagles released Chung after only one season, saving $2.25 million in cap space. His release was widely attributed to his injuries and issues in pass coverage. Problems with tackling and multiple incidents of accidentally delivering hits to teammates were also cited as possible reasons for his release.{{cite web| title=Philadelphia Eagles Release Patrick Chung| url=http://www.bleedinggreennation.com/2014/3/11/5497546/philadelphia-eagles-release-patrick-chung| accessdate=April 26, 2018| website=bleedinggreennation.com| date=March 11, 2013}} ===New England Patriots (second stint)=== On April 3, 2014, the New England Patriots signed Chung to a one-year, $1.10 million contract that includes a $120,000 guaranteed and a signing bonus of $60,000.{{cite web|work=NFL.com|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap2000000339225/article/patrick-chung-returning-to-new-england-patriots|title=Patrick Chung returning to New England Patriots|first=Chris|last=Wesseling|date=April 3, 2014|accessdate=2014-04-03}}{{cite web| title=Patrick Chung contract details| url=http://www.espn.com/blog/boston/new-england-patriots/post/_/id/4761186/patrick-chung-contract-details| accessdate=April 25, 2018| website=ESPN.com| author=Reiss, Mike| date=April 4, 2014}} Throughout training camp, Chung competed against [[Duron Harmon]] for the job as the starting strong safety after the Patriots elected not to re-sign starting strong safety Steve Gregory.{{cite web| title=Patriots Film Study: Duron Harmon, Patrick Chung Vie For Starting Safety Role| url=https://nesn.com/2014/06/patriots-film-study-duron-harmon-patrick-chung-vie-for-starting-safety-role/| accessdate=April 25, 2018| website=NESN.com| author=Kyed, Doug| date=June 17, 2014}} Head coach Bill Belichick named Chung the starter to begin the season, alongside free safety Devin McCourty.{{cite web| title=Ourlads.com: New England Patriots Depth Chart: 10/01/2014| url=http://www.ourlads.com/nfldepthcharts/archive/164/NE| accessdate=April 25, 2018| website=Ourlads.com}} On November 30, 2014, Chung collected a season-high 11 combined tackles (eight solo) during a 26–21 loss at the [[2014 Green Bay Packers|Green Bay Packers]] in Week 13. In Week 15, Chung made ten combined tackles (five solo), two pass deflections, and intercepted a pass by [[Ryan Tannehill]] in the Patriots' 41–13 win against the [[2014 Miami Dolphins season|Miami Dolphins]]. He finished the season with 85 combined tackles (54 solo), with pass deflections, and an interception in 16 games and 15 starts.{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/players/C/ChunPa99/gamelog/2014/ |title=Patrick Chung 2014 Game Log |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2017-12-29}} [[Pro Football Focus]] gave Chung an overall grade of 84.4 in 2014. The [[2014 New England Patriots|New England Patriots]] finished first in the AFC East with a 12–4 record, clinching a first round bye and home-field advantage. On January 10, 2015, Chung started in the AFC Divisional Round and recorded seven combined tackles during a 35–31 victory against the [[2014 Baltimore Ravens|Baltimore Ravens]]. The Patriots reached the Super Bowl after defeating the [[2014 Indianapolis Colts|Indianapolis Colts]] 45–7 in the AFC Championship Game. On February 1, 2015, Chung started in [[Super Bowl XLIX]] and made a solo tackle in their 28–24 victory against the [[2014 Seattle Seahawks|Seattle Seahawks]].{{cite web| title=NFL Player stats: Patrick Chung (2014)| url=http://www.nfl.com/player/patrickchung/71251/gamelogs?season=2014| accessdate=April 25, 2018| website=NFL.com}} ====2015==== On January 9, 2015, the New England Patriots signed Chung to a three-year, $8.20 million extension with $3.40 million guaranteed and a $2.40 million signing bonus.{{cite web|work=ESPN.com|url=http://espn.go.com/blog/new-england-patriots/post/_/id/4775840/patriots-sign-patrick-chung-to-extension|title=Patriots sign Patrick Chung to extension|first=Field|last=Yates|date=January 9, 2015|accessdate=2015-01-09}} On November 15, 2015, Chung collected a season-high 12 combined tackles (six solo) during a 27–26 victory at the [[2015 New York Giants|New York Giants]] in Week 10. He was inactive during the Patriots' Week 16 loss at the [[2015 New York Jets|New York Jets]] after injuring his hip the previous week.{{cite web| title=Patriots' injury list grows with WR Amendola, LB Hightower, CB Chung| url=http://www.espn.com/nfl/story/_/id/14410207/danny-amendola-donta-hightower-patrick-chung-injured-new-england-patriots-win-tennessee-titans| accessdate=April 25, 2018| website=ESPN.com| date=December 20, 2015}} He finished the season with 85 combined tackles (52 solo), nine pass deflections, and a forced fumble in 15 games and 14 starts.{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/players/C/ChunPa99/gamelog/2015 |title=Patrick Chung 2015 Game Log |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2017-12-29}} Chung received an overall grade of 88.4 from Pro Football Focus, which was sixth highest grade among all qualified safeties in 2015.{{cite web| title=5 Best NFL Safety Contracts| url=https://www.profootballfocus.com/news/pro-5-best-nfl-safety-contracts| accessdate=April 26, 2018| website=profootballfocus.com| date=July 8, 2016}} The [[2016 New England Patriots|New England Patriots]] finished atop the AFC East with a 12–4 record for the second consecutive season. On January 16, 2016, he made nine combined tackles during a 27–20 win against the [[2015 Kansas City Chiefs|Kansas City Chiefs]] in the AFC Divisional Round. The following week, Chung collected five combined tackles in the Patriots' 20–18 loss at the [[2015 Denver Broncos|Denver Broncos]] in the AFC Championship Game.{{cite web| title=NFL Player stats: Patrick Chung (2015)| url=http://www.nfl.com/player/patrickchung/71251/gamelogs?season=2015| accessdate=April 25, 2018| website=NFL.com}} ====2016==== On April 1, 2016, the New England Patriots signed Chung to a one-year, $5.70 million extension that includes $1.80 million guaranteed and a signing bonus of $800,000. The agreement kept him under contract throughout the {{NFL Year|2018}} season.{{cite web|title=Patriots sign Patrick Chung to one-year extension|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap3000000649476/article/patriots-sign-patrick-chung-to-oneyear-extension|author=Patra, Kevin|website=Patriots.com|date=April 1, 2016|accessdate=December 2, 2016}} On October 7, 2016, Chung made seven combined tackles, a pass deflection, and intercepted a pass by [[Charlie Whitehurst]] during a 33–13 win against the [[2016 Cleveland Browns|Cleveland Browns]] in Week 5.{{cite web| title=NFL Game Center: Week 5-2016: New England Patriots @ Cleveland Browns| url=http://www.nfl.com/gamecenter/2016100901/2016/REG5/patriots@browns| accessdate=April 26, 2018| website=NFL.com}} In Week 7, he collected a season-high 11 combined tackles (seven solo) and two pass deflections in the Patriots' 27–16 win at the [[2016 Pittsburgh Steelers|Pittsburgh Steelers]]. In Week 11, he collected nine combined tackles and sacked quarterback [[Colin Kaepernick]] in a 30–17 victory at the [[2016 San Francisco 49ers|San Francisco 49ers]].{{cite web| title=NFL Game Center: Week 11-2016: New England Patriots @ San Francisco 49ers| url=http://www.nfl.com/gamecenter/2016112009/2016/REG11/patriots@49ers| accessdate=April 26, 2018| website=NFL.com}} Chung finished the {{NFL Year|2016}} season with 91 combined tackles (52 solo), three pass deflections, an interception, and a sack in 16 games and 16 starts. He received an overall grade of 56.5 front Pro Football Focus in 2015.{{cite web| title=Patriots increase incentives in Chung's contract| url=https://www.profootballfocus.com/news/pro-patriots-increase-incentives-in-chungs-contract| accessdate=April 26, 2018| website=profootballfocus.com| date=June 18, 2016| author=Gellar, Cyrus}} The [[2016 New England Patriots|New England Patriots]] finished as the top seed with a 14-2 record.{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/teams/nwe/2016.htm |title=2016 New England Patriots Statistics & Players |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2017-12-29}} They went on to reach the Super Bowl after defeating the [[2016 Houston Texans|Houston Texans]] 34–16 in the AFC Divisional Round and the [[2016 Pittsburgh Steelers|Pittsburgh Steelers]] in the AFC Championship Game 36–17.{{cite web| title=NFL Player stats: Patrick Chung (2016)| url=http://www.nfl.com/player/patrickchung/71251/gamelogs?season=2016| accessdate=April 26, 2018| website=NFL.com}} On February 5, 2017, Chung recorded five combined tackles and two passes defended as the Patriots defeated the [[2016 Atlanta Falcons season|Atlanta Falcons]] by a score of 34–28 in overtime to win [[Super Bowl LI]].{{cite web|url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201702050atl.htm|title=Super Bowl LI - New England Patriots vs. Atlanta Falcons - February 5th, 2017|work=[[Pro-Football-Reference.com]]|accessdate=2 September 2017}} The Super Bowl featured the first overtime game and largest comeback in Super Bowl history.{{cite web|url=http://www.patriots.com/sites/patriots.com/files/20170205_gamebook_v2.pdf|title=Super Bowl LI - National Football League Game Summary|work=National Football League|accessdate=6 August 2017}} ====2017==== Head coach Bill Belichick retained Chung and McCourty as the starting safety duo to open the 2017 regular season.{{cite web| title=Ourlads.com: New England Patriots Depth Chart: 10/01/2017| url=http://www.ourlads.com/nfldepthcharts/archive/200/NE| accessdate=April 26, 2018| website=Ourlads.com}} In Week 10, Chung collected four solo tackles, broke up a pass, and returned an interception by [[Trevor Siemian]] for 30 yards in the Patriots' 41–16 win at the [[2017 Denver Broncos|Denver Broncos]]. On November 26, 2017, he made ten combined tackles (nine solo) during a 35–17 victory against the [[2017 Miami Dolphins|Miami Dolphins]] in Week 12. He finished the {{NFL Year|2017}} season with 84 combined tackles (71 solo), nine pass deflections, and a sack in 16 games and 11 starts. [[Pro Football Focus]] gave Chung an overall grade of 79.0 in 2017. His grade was the 42nd highest grade among all qualified safeties during the season.{{cite web| title=Pro Football Focus: Patrick Chung| url=https://www.profootballfocus.com/nfl/players/patrick-chung/4957| accessdate=April 26, 2018| website=profootballfocus.com}} The [[2017 New England Patriots|New England Patriots]] finished the season with a 13–3 record and clinched home-field advantage and a first round bye. They defeated the [[2017 Tennessee Titans|Tennessee Titans]] 35–14 in the AFC Divisional Round and the [[2017 Jacksonville Jaguars|Jacksonville Jaguars]] 24–20 in the AFC Championship to secure their second consecutive Super Bowl appearance. On February 4, 2018, Chung started in [[Super Bowl LII]] and made six combined tackles before exiting the game with a concussion.{{cite web|url=https://www.cbssports.com/fantasy/football/news/patriots-patrick-chung-exits-super-bowl-with-concussion/|title=Patriots' Patrick Chung: Exits Super Bowl with concussion|publisher=''[[CBS Sports]]''|date=February 4, 2018}} The New England Patriots were defeated by the [[2017 Philadelphia Eagles|Philadelphia Eagles]] 41–33.{{cite web| title=NFL Player stats: Patrick Chung (2017)| url=http://www.nfl.com/player/patrickchung/71251/gamelogs?season=2017| accessdate=April 26, 2018| website=NFL.com}} ====2018==== On March 19, 2018, the New England Patriots signed Chung to a two-year, $7.80 million contract extension with $5.12 million guaranteed and a signing bonus of $3.60 million, keeping him under contract through the 2020 season.{{cite web|title=Patriots Rewarding Patrick Chung With Major Pay Raise In Contract Extension|url=https://nesn.com/2018/03/patriots-rewarding-patrick-chung-with-major-pay-raise-in-contract-extension/|author=Kyed, Doug|website=NESN.com|date=March 19, 2018}} Chung was also named a team captain for the first time.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/sports/patriots/2018/09/06/first-timers-patrick-chung-and-james-white-among-six-captains-named-patriots/tmwsXpIalt4KwowHIoa3JJ/story.html|title=First-timers Patrick Chung and James White among six captains named by Patriots - The Boston Globe|work=BostonGlobe.com|access-date=2018-09-17}} ==Career statistics== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- ! {{Infobox artist | honorific_prefix = | name = | honorific_suffix = | image = Пётр Захаров-Чеченец - Автопортрет (1833-1834).jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | birth_name = | birth_date = 1816 | birth_place = Dadi-yurt | death_date = 1846 | death_place = [[Moscow]] | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{Coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline}} --> | nationality = | residence = | education = | alma_mater = | known_for = | notable_works = | style = | movement = | spouse = | partner = | awards = | elected = | patrons = | memorials = | website = | module = }} '''Pyotr Zakharovich Zakharov-Chechenets''' ({{lang-ru|Пётр Захарович Захаров-Чеченец}}; 1816 – 1846) was a [[Russia]]n painter of [[Chechen people|Chechen]] origin. He is believed to be the only professional painter of Chechen origin in the 19th century.<ref name="stranaru">[http://kavkaz.strana.ru/catalogue/culture/88148.html Grozny Art Museum] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070425195247/http://kavkaz.strana.ru/catalogue/culture/88148.html |date=2007-04-25 }} {{ru icon}}</ref><ref name="chechenorg">[http://www.chechen.org/modules.php?name=Known&letter=%C7&sortby=cname Biography of famous Chechens] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070405054406/http://www.chechen.org/modules.php?name=Known |date=2007-04-05 }} {{ru icon}}</ref>
== Biography == In 1819, during the [[Caucasian War]] Russian troops found a dead woman and a dying wounded three-year-old baby in the Chechen [[aul]] Dady-Yurt. The [[commander-in-chief]] of the Russian army [[Aleksey Petrovich Yermolov]] ordered military medics to do everything possible to save this baby despite all medical advice saying that it was impossible. Against all the odds, the baby survived.<ref name="ruhist">[http://www.sgu.ru/rus_hist/authors/?aid=665 Article P.Zakharov on the ''Russian History in the mirror of visual arts'' site] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070227102638/http://www.sgu.ru/rus_hist/authors/?aid=665 |date=2007-02-27 }} {{ru icon}}</ref> The baby was given for nursing to [[Cossack]] Zakhar Nedonosov. From the name of this Cossack, the baby got his surname and [[patronymic]].<ref name="freechechen">[http://www.chechnyafree.ru/index.php?lng=rus&section=fcultrus&row=5 ''Zakharov-Chechenets'' article on the ''Chechen Cultural Figures'' site]</ref> Later Pyotr appended the word Chechenets to his surname in order to show his ethnic identity.
At the age of seven, Pyotr was adopted by [[Major-General]] Pyotr Yermolov, Commanger of a [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]]n [[Grenadier]] regiment and a cousin of Aleksey Petrovich Yermolov.<ref name="ruhist"/> Pyotr Yermolov liked Zakharov very much and, despite having seven children of his own, treated him as his own son.<ref name="chechenorg"/>
The boy showed talent in painting and Pyotr Yermolov tried to send him to the [[Imperial Academy of Arts]] in [[Saint Petersburg]] but the president of the Academy, [[Aleksey Olenin]], claimed that the 10-year-old boy was too young to study at the Academy and recommended hiring a private teacher. So, the boy got lessons from the portraitist Lev Volkov.
Eventually, at the age of 17, Zakharov entered the Academy. He graduated in 1835 with a diploma of ''Free Artist'' and was recommended for a scholarship to study art in Italy. The trip might have been helpful for both his artistic growth and for his health, which had begun to show signs of [[tuberculosis]]. However, his name was withdrawn from the list for the scholarship by Emperor [[Nicholas I of Russia]] who insisted that [[national minorities]] (''[[inorodtsy]]'') should not benefit from the Academy's scholarships.<ref name="freechechen"/> Another misfortune followed as Zakarov's first teacher, Lev Volkov, refused to allow his daughter to marry Zakharov despite the young people being in love. Instead Volkov had her sent to relatives in the Caucasus with an order to marry her off to any first-comer just to stop the affair.<ref name="freechechen"/>
Zakharov soon became a fashionable portraitist. His clients included the favorite daughter of Nicholas I, [[Grand Duchess Maria Nikolayevna, Duchess of Leuchtenberg|Grand Duchess Maria Nikolayevna]] and her future husband [[Maximilian, Duke of Leuchtenberg]].<ref name="ruhist"/> In 1837, he was admitted to the state service as an Artist in the Military Department.<ref name="ruhist"/> In 1842, his [[:Image:Zkharov-Yermolov.jpg|Portrait of Aleksey Petrovich Yermolov]] qualified him to become a member of the Academy of Arts.<ref name="Brockhaus">[http://www.cultinfo.ru/fulltext/1/001/007/041/41358.htm ''Pyotr Zakharov'']{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} in the [[Brockhaus and Efron Encyclopedic Dictionary]] {{ru icon}}</ref>
On 14 January 1846, Zakharov married, <!-- No idea if it was Miss Volkov or somebody else --> but their happiness was short. On 13 June 1846, his wife died from tuberculosis.Zakharov died from the same disease a few months later.<ref name="ruhist"/>
Many works of Zakharov-Chechenets are kept in the [[Tretyakov Gallery]] and in the [[Russian Museum]]. The Art Museum in the capital of [[Chechnya]], [[Grozny]] also used to have many of his works including his ''Selfportrait, and ''Portrait of I.F. Ladygensky''. In 1995 during the [[First Chechen War]] the Grozny Museum was heavily damaged and the paintings were all but destroyed. Since 1995, they are being restored at the ''Grabar Restoration Center'' in [[Moscow]].<ref name="stranaru"/>
==Works== <gallery> File:Пётр Захаров-Чеченец - Автопортрет (1833-1834).jpg|Self-portrait as a young man File:Zkharov-Yermolov.jpg|Portrait of [[Aleksey Petrovich Yermolov]], 1842 File:ZaharovP PtDetPErmolovaGTG.jpg|Children of Pyotr Yermolov, 1839 File:ZakharovPZ PtTGranovskogoGTG.jpg|Portrait of historian [[Timofey Granovsky]], 1845 </gallery>
== Memory == [[File:Петр Захаров 130.jpg|thumb|right|Monument installed in the park named after Pyotr Zakharov.]] * Pyotr Zakharov is depicted on the sketch of Michael Scotty "The Armenian Nerses and the Chechen Zakharov" (1836)<ref>{{cite web |author = Маркина Людмила |title = Работы художника Петра Захарова в собрании Третьяковской галереи |url = http://www.tg-m.ru/img/mag/2011/3/07.pdf |date = 2011 |work = tg-m.ru |publisher = Третьяковская галерея |accessdate = 2018-04-17 }}</ref>. * Zakharov is depicted in the painting by landscape painter [[Grigory Chernetsov]] "Parade on October 6, 1831 in St. Petersburg." The list of persons who were to be depicted in the picture was approved personally by [[Nicholas I of Russia|Emperor Nicholas I]]. In the subsequently published list of characters from among the spectators, Zakharov appeared under the number 204<ref>Шахбиева М. Х. Пётр Захаров-Чеченец — известный и неизвестный // Дош : magazine. — 2016. — No 2. — p. 62—64.</ref>. * Pyotr's painting Empty Pasture in Afternoon appears prominently in [[Anthony Marra]]'s book ''The Tsar of Love and Techno: Stories. '' * Before the [[first Chechen war]] in [[Grozny]] worked the Chechen-Ingush Republican Museum of Fine Arts named after Pyotr Zakharov. * In 2016 the name of Pyotr Zakharov was awarded to the Grozny children's art school No. 2<ref>{{cite web|title=О присвоении детской художественной школе города Грозного имени академика Петра Захарова|url=http://grozgorduma.ru/index.php/deyatelnost/resheniya?task=callelement&format=raw&item_id=1636&element=591a7986-68c8-4325-9b42-2854e08f7aea&method=download&file=documents/uploads/re6enie75.pdf|date=2016-12-23|work=grozgorduma.ru|accessdate=2017-09-29|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170929183100/http://grozgorduma.ru/index.php/deyatelnost/resheniya?task=callelement&format=raw&item_id=1636&element=591a7986-68c8-4325-9b42-2854e08f7aea&method=download&file=documents%2Fuploads%2Fre6enie75.pdf|archive-date=2017-09-29|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>. * October 5, 2017 in [[Grozny]] opened a park named after Pyotr Zakharov<ref>{{cite web|author=Хава Кадиева|title=В Грозном открылся Сквер им. Петра Захарова|url=https://chechnyatoday.com/content/view/306994|date=2017-10-05|work=chechnyatoday.com|publisher=Чечня сегодня|accessdate=2018-03-31}}</ref>.
